Package algorithms.imageProcessing

Class CIEChromaticity

java.lang.Object
algorithms.imageProcessing.CIEChromaticity
public class CIEChromaticity extends Object
convenience methods for color space not present in jdk. see http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/vision/cie.html and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIE_1931_color_space#mediaviewer/File:CIE1931xy_blank.svg and
Author:
nichole

    • rgbToPolarCIELUV

      public float[] rgbToPolarCIELUV(int r, int g, int b)
      convert rgb to polar coordinates of CIELUV (a.k.a. CIEL*A*B* 1976?) CIE 1976 (L*, u*, v*). uses http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIE_1931_color_space#Experimental_results:_the_CIE_RGB_color_space and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lab_color_space#Forward_transformation 
       using the standard illuminant of daylight, D65,
 the range of return values is
     range of CIE LUV using default standard illumination of
        D65 daylight is:
        L       0 to 104.5
        u   -86.9 to 183.8
        v  -141.4 to 112.3
        luminosity L*  0 to 104.5
        magnitude, m:  sqrt(2) * 183.8 = 260
        angle,     a:  0 to 359
      Parameters:
      r - in range 0 to 255, inclusive
      g - in range 0 to 255, inclusive
      b - in range 0 to 255, inclusive
      Returns:
      luv[0], (float)m, (float)t where the first item is luminosity, the second is the magnitude of the color, that is sqrt of square sums of U and V, and the third is the polar theta angle

      convert rgb to polar coordinates of CIELUV. CIE 1976 (L*, u*, v*) uses http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIE_1931_color_space#Experimental_results:_the_CIE_RGB_color_space and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lab_color_space#Forward_transformation range of return values for L* magnitude: angle: 0 to 359
      Parameters:
      r -
      g -
      b -
      Xn - standard illuminant
      Yn - standard illuminant
      Zn - standard illuminant
      Returns:

    • rgbToCIELUV_WideRangeLightness

      public float[] rgbToCIELUV_WideRangeLightness(int r, int g, int b)
      convert rgb to CIELUV. CIE 1976 (L*, u*, v*) uses http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIE_1931_color_space#Experimental_results:_the_CIE_RGB_color_space and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lab_color_space#Forward_transformation uses standard illuminant "wide range lightness". Wide-range Lightness data were generated by Fairchild et al., who conducted two different experiments to scale lightness above and below diffuse white (CIE * L = 100 ). In the Scaling Lightness Experiment 1 (SL1) they used a luminance range from 156 to 2 3692cd m with 2 842 Y cd m n = (Yn represents the luminance of reference white) whereas in the Scaling Lightness Experiment 2 (SL2) the luminance range was extended from 0 to 2 7432cd m with 2 997 Y cd m n = . The SL2 data set was used to drive the adapted lightness ( z J ) formula of the proposed color space (see later) while the SL1 data set was used as a test data set. Each of the sets includes 19 samples. https://www.osapublishing.org/DirectPDFAccess/B810E9AE-C7C9-E594-C72DC7FBE1424F0A_368272/oe-25-13-15131.pdf?da=1&id=368272&seq=0&mobile=no SL2 Training D65/2Â° (x,y,z)=968.08 997 883.51 L_a=199 C=0.69. N_C=1, F=1 range of return values is: L 0 to 104.8 u -99.9 to 176.8 v -150.0 to 95.0
      Parameters:
      r - in range 0 to 255, inclusive
      g - in range 0 to 255, inclusive
      b - in range 0 to 255, inclusive
      Returns:

    • rgbToCIELUV

      public float[] rgbToCIELUV(int r, int g, int b)
      convert rgb to CIE LUV (a.k.a. CIEL*A*B* 1976) CIE 1976 (L*, u*, v*) Note that differences in CIELUV are simply the differences in each component added in quadrature (no deltaE formula). uses http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIE_1931_color_space#Experimental_results:_the_CIE_RGB_color_space and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lab_color_space#Forward_transformation http://www.easyrgb.com/index.php?X=MATH&H=16#text16 range of return values when using default standard illumination of D65 daylight is: L 0 to 104.5 u -86.9 to 183.8 v -141.4 to 112.3
      Parameters:
      r -
      g -
      b -
      Returns:

    • rgbToCIELUV

      public float[] rgbToCIELUV(int r, int g, int b, float Xn, float Yn, float Zn)
      convert rgb to CIE LUV (a.k.a. CIEL*A*B* 1976?) CIE 1976 (L*, u*, v*) and use the given standard illumination in tristimulus coordinates. 
            Incandescent:
          109.850, 100, 35.585
          range of return values for incandescent
           L       0 to 104.5
           u  -156.2 to 141.6
           v  -172.0 to 45.6
      Daylight, midday (D65):
          95.047, 100, 108.883
          range of return values for D65
           L       0 to 104.5
           u   -86.9 to 183.8
           v  -141.4 to 112.3
      Fluorescent:
          99.187, 100, 67.395
          range of return values for Fluorescent
           L       0 to 104.5
           u  -113.6 to 167.5
           v  -158.5 to 75.0
      D75:
          94.972,  100, 122.638
          range of return values for D75
           L       0 to 104.5
           u   -81.7 to 186.9
           v  -136.2 to 124.5
      uses http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIE_1931_color_space#Experimental_results:_the_CIE_RGB_color_space and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lab_color_space#Forward_transformation http://www.easyrgb.com/index.php?X=MATH&H=16#text16
      Parameters:
      r -
      g -
      b -
      Xn - standard illuminant X
      Yn - standard illuminant Y #param Zn standard illuminant Z
      Returns:

    • _rgbToCIEXYZ

      public float[] _rgbToCIEXYZ(int r, int g, int b)
      convert rgb to CIE XYZ (1931). uses http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIE_1931_color_space#Experimental_results:_the_CIE_RGB_color_space normalizes the r,g,b values to lie between 0 and 1.0 assuming the arguments are given as a range 0 to 255. for r=0, g=0, b=0, CIEXY is (0, 0, 0). for r=1, g=1, b=1, CIEXY is (5.65, 5.65, 5.65)
      Parameters:
      r -
      g -
      b -
      Returns:

    • _rgbToCIEXYZ

      public float[] _rgbToCIEXYZ(float r, float g, float b)
      convert rgb to CIE XYZ (1931). uses http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIE_1931_color_space#Experimental_results:_the_CIE_RGB_color_space expects r,g,b values between 0 and 1, inclusive. for r=0, g=0, b=0, CIEXY is (0, 0, 0). for r=1, g=1, b=1, CIEXY is (5.65, 5.65, 5.65)
      Parameters:
      r -
      g -
      b -
      Returns:

    • _rgbToCIEXYZ2

      public float[] _rgbToCIEXYZ2(float r, float g, float b)
      convert rgb to CIE XYZ (1931). uses http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CIE_1931_color_space#Experimental_results:_the_CIE_RGB_color_space expects r,g,b values between 0 and 1, inclusive. for r=0, g=0, b=0, CIEXY is (0, 0, 0). for r=1, g=1, b=1, CIEXY is (5.65, 5.65, 5.65)
      Parameters:

      g -
      b -
      Returns:

    • cieXYZToCIELAB

      public float[] cieXYZToCIELAB(float[] cieXYZ)
      convert CIE XYZ (1931) to CIE LAB. uses https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lab_color_space#Forward_transformation L is from 0 to 100 a is from - to + (negative are green, pos are red) b is from - to + (negative are blue, pos are yellow) to change the reference point, see http://www.easyrgb.com/index.php?X=MATH&H=15#text15
      Parameters:
      cieXYZ -
      Returns:

    • cieXYZToCIELCH

      public float[] cieXYZToCIELCH(float[] cieXYZ)

      Parameters:
      cieXYZ -
      Returns:

    • calcDeltaECIE76

      public double calcDeltaECIE76(float[] cieLAB1, float[] cieLAB2)
      calculate the CIE76 delta E for 2 sets of CIE LAB. uses https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_difference the "Just noticeable difference", JND, begins at E_ab ~ 2.3
      Parameters:
      cieLAB1 -
      cieLAB2 -
      Returns:
      deltaE

    • calcDeltaECIE94

      public double calcDeltaECIE94(float[] cieLAB1, float[] cieLAB2)
      calculate the CIE76 delta E for 2 sets of CIE LAB. uses https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_difference the "Just noticeable difference", JND, begins at E_ab ~ 2.3 the range of resulting values is 0 through 28.78.
      Parameters:
      cieLAB1 -
      cieLAB2 -
      Returns:
      deltaE

    • calcDeltaECIE94

      public double calcDeltaECIE94(float ell1, float a1, float b1, float ell2, float a2, float b2)
      calculate the delta E 1994 for 2 sets of CIE LAB. uses https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_difference the "Just noticeable difference", JND, begins at E_ab ~ 2.3. the range of resulting values is 0 through 28.78.
      Returns:
      deltaE

    • calcDeltaECIE2000

      public double calcDeltaECIE2000(float[] lab1, float[] lab2)
      calculate the delta E 2000 for 2 sets of CIE LAB, specifically, CIEDE2000. uses https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_difference and http://www.ece.rochester.edu/~gsharma/ciede2000/ciede2000noteCRNA.pdf Sharma, Wu, and Dalal 2004 The implementation is adapted from https://github.com/wuchubuzai/OpenIMAJ/blob/master/image/image-processing/src/main/java/org/openimaj/image/analysis/colour/CIEDE2000.java which has copyright 2011, The University of Southampton and allows redistribution of source with or without modification. Note that the "Just noticeable difference", JND, begins at E_ab ~ 2.3. The range of resulting values if CIELUV values are given is 0 to about 130-ish. The range of resulting values if CIELAB1931 values are given is 0 to about 120-ish.
      Returns:
      deltaE

    • calcDeltaECIE2000

      public double calcDeltaECIE2000(float L1, float a1, float b1, float L2, float a2, float b2)
      calculate the delta E 2000 for 2 sets of CIE LAB, specifically, CIEDE2000. see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_difference and http://www.ece.rochester.edu/~gsharma/ciede2000/ciede2000noteCRNA.pdf Sharma, Wu, and Dalal 2004 The implementation is adapted from https://github.com/wuchubuzai/OpenIMAJ/blob/master/image/image-processing/src/main/java/org/openimaj/image/analysis/colour/CIEDE2000.java which has copyright 2011, The University of Southampton and allows redistribution of source with or without modification. Note that the "Just noticeable difference", JND, begins at E_ab ~ 2.3. The range of resulting values if CIELUV values are given is 0 to about 130-ish. The range of resulting values if CIELAB1931 values are given is 0 to about 120-ish.
      Returns:
      deltaE

    • rgbToCIEXYZ

      Parameters:

      g -
      b -
      outputCIEXYZ - output array of length 3 that will be populated with cieX, cieY and cieZ.

    • isWhite2

      public boolean isWhite2(float cieX, float cieY)
      returns roughly whether the CIE (X,Y) coordinate lands within the large white zone in the center of the diagram. Note that this returns true for grey too, so test for lower intensities first
      Parameters:
      cieX -
      cieY -
      Returns:

    • calculateXYTheta

      public double calculateXYTheta(float cieX, float cieY)
      calculate the angle in radians of the point (cieX, cieY) in the CIE chromaticity diagram with respect to an origin of (0.35, 0.35). Note that one should check for white before using this as the resulting angle will not be a significant answer if it is. The angles are 
          90(=pi/2)
            |
            |
   180 ----------- 0
   (=pi)    |
            |
          270(=3pi/2)
      Parameters:
      cieX -
      cieY -
      Returns:
      the angle in radians of the point (cieX, cieY) with respect to an origin of (0.35, 0.35). The invoker should check the original r,g,b for black and white to avoid use here. A value of -1 is returned for white.

    • isInLargeWhiteCenter

      public boolean isInLargeWhiteCenter(float cieX, float cieY)
      Is within the bounds of large white central region in the CIE 1931 xy chromaticity diagram. Note that this region has small amount of color in it too, so you may want to further process any point in rgb too. Also note that grey pixels are found here too centered at (0.33, 0.33).
      Parameters:
      cieX -
      cieY -
      Returns:

    • calcNormalizedDifferenceLAB31

      public float calcNormalizedDifferenceLAB31(float ell1, float a1, float b1, float ell2, float a2, float b2)
      calculate the difference in L,A,B 1931 between between the two sets and normalize the values to a sum of "1" using the range of values possible from the use of a standard illuminant, D65.
      Returns:

    • calcNormalizedDifferenceLUV_WideRangeLightness

      public float calcNormalizedDifferenceLUV_WideRangeLightness(int r1, int g1, int b1, int r2, int g2, int b2)
      calculate the difference in L, U, V 1976 WideRangeLightness between between the two sets and normalize the values to a sum of "1" using the range of values possible. * uses standard illuminant "wide range lightness". Wide-range Lightness data were generated by Fairchild et al., who conducted two different experiments to scale lightness above and below diffuse white (CIE * L = 100 ). In the Scaling Lightness Experiment 1 (SL1) they used a luminance range from 156 to 2 3692cd m with 2 842 Y cd m n = (Yn represents the luminance of reference white) whereas in the Scaling Lightness Experiment 2 (SL2) the luminance range was extended from 0 to 2 7432cd m with 2 997 Y cd m n = . The SL2 data set was used to drive the adapted lightness ( z J ) formula of the proposed color space (see later) while the SL1 data set was used as a test data set. Each of the sets includes 19 samples. https://www.osapublishing.org/DirectPDFAccess/B810E9AE-C7C9-E594-C72DC7FBE1424F0A_368272/oe-25-13-15131.pdf?da=1&id=368272&seq=0&mobile=no SL2 Training D65/2Â° (x,y,z)=968.08 997 883.51 L_a=199 C=0.69. N_C=1, F=1
      Returns:

    • calcNormalizedDifferenceLUV_WideRangeLightness
